explanation:
To determine whether OS_MutSemGetInfo violates the MISRA rule banning direct or indirect recursion, the analyzer must inspect not only its body but also any function it calls (and those functions' callees) that could form a call cycle back to OS_MutSemGetInfo. The required symbols and why each is needed:

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: Direct callee of OS_MutSemGetInfo. Must be checked for any transitive calls that could reach OS_MutSemGetInfo.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById; include to verify it does not call back into OS_MutSemGetInfo.
- OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById; include to verify no back-call to OS_MutSemGetInfo.
- OS_ObjectIdConvertToken: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById; include for the same reason.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById; include for the same reason.
- OS_ObjectIdRelease: Direct callee of OS_MutSemGetInfo. Must be inspected for transitive calls that could create recursion.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish: Callee of OS_ObjectIdRelease; include to verify no path back to OS_MutSemGetInfo.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Direct callee (appears in static graph); include even if it has no callees to confirm it cannot call back.
- OS_MutSemGetInfo_Impl: Direct callee that implements platform-specific behavior; must be inspected because it could (in implementation) call OS_MutSemGetInfo or another function that does.
- OS_printf: Direct callee (present in static graph). Though typically not recursive here, its implementation or handlers it invokes could indirectly call back; must be checked.
- OS_ConsoleWrite: Callee of OS_printf; include to ensure no transitive call path back to OS_MutSemGetInfo.

The UT (unit-test/stub) framework functions listed below are required because they can register handlers/return values or execute user-provided handlers; those handlers can invoke arbitrary code (including OS_MutSemGetInfo), potentially producing indirect recursion. To be safe, their internals and the mechanism by which they invoke handlers must be analyzed:

- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType: Called by tested code paths (in graph); must be checked to see whether stub registration or invocation can introduce a callback into OS_MutSemGetInfo.
- UT_GetStubEntry: Used by UT stub APIs; include to see how handlers/registered callbacks are stored or invoked.
- UT_ClearStubEntry: Related to stub lifecycle; include to understand invocation behaviour.
- UtAssert_Abort: Included because some UT internals reference it; include to trace possible control-flow into test callbacks.
- UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData: Registers context/metadata for stubs; can be part of callback mechanism.
- UT_ExecuteBasicHandler: Invokes stub handlers; essential to check whether execution of a registered handler could call OS_MutSemGetInfo.
- UT_SetHandlerFunction: Part of handler registration mechanism; include to trace what functions may be invoked by the UT framework.
- UT_DefaultStubImpl: The default implementation invoked by the UT framework; include to see whether it can call back into production code.
- UT_ExecuteVaHandler: Variant that executes variadic handlers invoked by OS_printf; include because OS_printf may route through it.
- UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr: Used to obtain return-value pointers from stubs; include because it participates in stub invocation/control flow.
- UtAssert_GetContext: Utility used by UT framework when invoking assertions/handlers; include to fully understand callback invocation paths.

In short: include all direct callees of OS_MutSemGetInfo and their immediate callees (from the static graph), plus the UT framework internals that can invoke registered handlers. Inspecting these symbols will allow a complete transitive call-graph analysis to determine whether any path exists that leads from OS_MutSemGetInfo back to itself (directly or indirectly), which is required to decide MISRA conformity for recursion.
